I.</br>Spirit!  that nor in air, nor sea, nor earth,</br>Our grosser mortal sight hath known;</br>Whose heavenly nature speaks a heavenly birth,</br>The world thy kingdom, man's firm mind thy throne;</br>Genius!  thou emblem of Divinity!</br>If aught, save the Eternal-one,</br>Could claim the bended knee,</br>To thee should earthly homage bow alone,</br>And worship his high attribute in thee!</br>Thou only pure unchangeable,</br>Amidst a world of change;</br>Whose never-dying principle,</br>Through ages and through climes can range,</br>Like molten gold unmixed remain,</br>And undebased unite again;</br>Ductile to all that virtuous is and good,</br>Nor ever with the wicked blending:—</br>Genius!  at thy mysterious altars bending,</br>A thousand tongues thy power proclaim,</br>A thousand bards exalt thy fame,</br>A thousand lyres re-echo to thy name,</br>But none hath raised th' impenetrable hood:</br>Shrouded by "excess of light,"</br>More than by Cimmerian night,</br>Still hath thy power been felt, but never understood!

II.</br>Unsearchable thy source; and vain</br>It were to seek the hidden chain,</br>Th' electric impulse, sudden, bright,</br>That flashes forth thy radiant light.</br>We hear the clash, we see the blaze,</br>But He alone, who formed the maze</br>Of man's wild trackless mind;</br>He only knows the magic sweet,</br>Which bids the maddening pulses beat,</br>And spreads unseen its vital heat,</br>Like sun-beams on the blind.</br>Enough for us in every race,</br>Which time and war and vice have spared,</br>Th' unconquerable flame to trace;</br>The sacred ashes guard.

III.</br>Nursed in Beauty's native clime,</br>Where love lay hid in myrtle bowers;</br>Whence sprang old Homer's lay sublime;</br>Whence Sophocles' and Pindar's powers?</br>Whence but from thee?  Oh ne'er again,</br>So bright, so godlike shalt thou reign,</br>As when the bards of Greece arose,</br>Victorious o'er thy deadly foes,</br>And vanquished Space and Time.</br>Yes, proudly eminent they stand,</br>The glory of their fallen land!</br>Vain was in sculptured domes thy trust:</br>Vainly thou breath'd'st in every bust;</br>Thy gorgeous temples sink to dust!</br>Of Phidias mangled heaps remain;</br>Of Xeuxis, but a name;</br>Whilst slumbering nations wake at Homer's strain,</br>And dazzled votaries veil at Pindar's flame.</br>Thy mortal body fades away;</br>Thy soul immortal springs to deathless day!</br>Alas, how changed thy classic scene;</br>Still Athens breathes her air serene;</br>Still fragrance down her vallies floats;</br>Still echo there in softened notes</br>Sweet Songs of Love from Maidens fair;</br>But vanished now is Greece's spell</br>Her cities of the Spoiler tell;</br>Degenerate and unmourned she fell,</br>When weeping Genius fled before Despair.

IV.</br>Where didst thou fly?  Imperial Rome,</br>With thee awhile the Spirit staid;</br>And vassal nations owned thy doom,</br>And the world trembled and obeyed.</br>Then Virgil's song and Tully's speech,</br>Seemed half the Grecian strength to reach;</br>Till luxury and vice with victory came,</br>And Genius fled away!—</br>Where heavenly Spirit did'st thou stray</br>Thro' that long night in which no genial ray</br>Flashed thy undying flame?</br>Say, didst thou seek in rosy bowers,</br>The lovely maids of Cachmire's vale,</br>Re-echoing through the moonlight hours,</br>The warblings of the Nightingale?</br>Or didst thou wake in Iceland's storms,</br>The magic notes of Odin's shell,</br>And 'mid Valhalla's shadowy forms,</br>Sing those who conquered, those who fell?</br>Or did'st thou in a world unknown,</br>Pour the wild Indian's warlike tone,</br>Where courage, seeking but to die,</br>Climbs undesigned the heights of Poesy?

V.</br>Still lingering in thy lovely Italy,</br>When Europe from her trance awoke,</br>Thy meteor fire in Dante's vision broke,</br>And in Orlando's tale of witchery.</br>Then was it quenched: — and then was heard,</br>In northern climes thy gifted word.</br>Scarce on the flowery plains of France,</br>Ethereal Genius, did'st thou glance;</br>Scarce from the mitred prelate roll,</br>One peal of eloquence to wake the soul;</br>While England, happy England, was thy home!</br>O never more to roam!</br>Shakspeare and Spenser claimed thee all;</br>And he who sang of Eden's fall,</br>Sightless himself to give to others sight;</br>And the long train of Bards in heaven-born radiance bright.</br>O Genius of the liquid lay!</br>How sweetly in her evil day,</br>O'er Albion's hills thy visions play,</br>And breathe thy spirit ever;</br>Here fix thy dwelling-place and say,</br>"England, I leave thee never."

VI.</br>O vain and idle prayer!  To give</br>Unbounded spirit bounds to live!</br>Where liv'st thou not?  Let pedants tell,</br>That only shut in Learning's cell,</br>Or in the Minstrel's lighter spell,</br>Thy magic shines confest;</br>Still let them pour their narrow strife;</br>Thou liv'st wherever man has life!</br>Wherever love can warm the breast,</br>Where'er the hero's glories rest;</br>Where'er the peasant's mountain nest,</br>Is snatched from tyranny.</br>Yes!  from Arabia's burning zone,</br>To where from giant nature's gorgeous throne,</br>The northern Indian views lake, river, tree,</br>Majestic as the sky's bright panoply,</br>And calls them all his own,</br>The earth his vassal, man, man only free!</br>Yes, even there, or on the Lapland rock,</br>Which seems the sounding surge to mock,</br>The Fisher whose unceasing toil,</br>From Ocean plucks his scanty spoil,</br>And, like the eagle in his eyrie, shares</br>With one dear mate, his joys, his griefs, his cares;</br>Yes even with him, blest Genius, may'st thou dwell,</br>And though the grand ideas that swell,</br>His bursting spirit, scarce his tongue can tell,</br>Yet not extinct, tho' smothered is thy flame,</br>And brighter the wild flash that none may claim,</br>And dearer is its power,</br>To cheer the toilsome hour,</br>Than the forced sickly blaze that lends wit's flickering fame.</br>Genius!  presumptuous reason may not dare</br>Thy bounds to scan;</br>But where is love, and liberty, and man,</br>Genius, thou wilt be there!</br>
